Comment: White decides to contrast with the movie and open with e3. I rarely see skilled players attempting this opening, so of course I got a little nervous from the beginning.
So I open the GK database and start analysing options I was comfortable with, starting here...
Transposing into a queenside opening. I usually see varations of this in QGD.
So I decide to pull out Ron! And mostly just stick him there for most of that match.
White decides to contest d5-e4, rather than throw off the d5 pawn with c4 as per QG.
I plan e6 anyway, so I may as well not block in the LSB.
More development.
I continue with my plan.
White decides Harry Potter is too much of an annoying kid to bother the king on b4. Probably true.
And I fully transpose into my usual QGD play, since I'm most familiar with it on this type of board.
White accepts the Gambit.
Expeliarmus!
No using Magic on mere Muggles!
Run away Harry!
? - Not sure about the check. I preferred Be2...
Now, if the bishop takes here, I can decide who captures back later, as opposed to Nc6 where if Bxc6+, the only move is bxc6.
White decides to take a break and move the kings away from danger.
I oblige, freeing the pin on my knight.
My assumption was that White felt as though my LSB was actually doing anything at all. Or maybe Bg4 was actually a real threat. I couldn't see how.
But I retreat the bishop here anyway, interested in seeing what White was planning.
